unnormalised: Okay, so I just had to share my experience with everyone. Being pregnant in India is… well, it’s an experience! Especially when you’re trying to navigate the whole Obstetrics and Gynecology world. My gynecologist, Dr. Aisha Khan, at Apollo Clinic (that’s Dr. Khan, MBBS, MD, DNB for all the qualifications!), she's been a lifesaver, honestly.
normalised: Okay, so I just had to share my experience with everyone. Being pregnant in India is… well, it’s an experience! Especially when you’re trying to navigate the whole Obstetrics and Gynecology world. My gynecologist, Doctor Aisha Khan, at Apollo Clinic (that’s Doctor Khan, M-B-B-S, M-D, D-N-B for all the qualifications!), she's been a lifesaver, honestly.

unnormalised: Finding a good OB-GYN is seriously like finding a needle in a haystack. I mean, every aunty from my building has an opinion, right? “Oh, you must go to Dr. Sharma! She delivered both my grandsons!” But seriously, you gotta do your research. I was freaking out about everything – pre-natal vitamins, the scan timings, the whole labour process. Google became my best friend… and my worst enemy!
normalised: Finding a good O-B-G-Y-N is seriously like finding a needle in a haystack. I mean, every aunty from my building has an opinion, right? “Oh, you must go to Doctor Sharma! She delivered both my grandsons!” But seriously, you gotta do your research. I was freaking out about everything – pre-natal vitamins, the scan timings, the whole labor process. Google became my best friend… and my worst enemy!

unnormalised: Then there are the cultural expectations. Everyone expects you to eat for two! My nani keeps saying, "Beta, have another laddoo!" And the sheer volume of advice! From what to eat to how to sleep – EVERYONE has an opinion. It’s all well-meaning, of course, but sometimes it gets a bit overwhelming. And the questions! "Beta, is it a boy or a girl?" Like it's their business, ya know? I mean, I only had my first ultrasound at 12 weeks!
normalised: Then there are the cultural expectations. Everyone expects you to eat for two! My nani keeps saying, "Beta, have another laddoo!" And the sheer volume of advice! From what to eat to how to sleep – EVERYONE has an opinion. It’s all well-meaning, of course, but sometimes it gets a bit overwhelming. And the questions! "Beta, is it a boy or a girl?" Like it's their business, ya know? I mean, I only had my first ultrasound at twelve weeks!

unnormalised: The biggest thing I've realised is the importance of regular checkups. Dr. Khan insisted I come in every month, and towards the end, it was almost weekly! The sheer number of tests is enough to make your head spin – blood tests, urine tests, glucose tolerance tests… I felt like a pincushion! And don't even get me started on the costs. I remember the 1st trimester scan cost me Rs. 3500/-.
normalised: The biggest thing I've realized is the importance of regular checkups. Doctor Khan insisted I come in every month, and towards the end, it was almost weekly! The sheer number of tests is enough to make your head spin – blood tests, urine tests, glucose tolerance tests… I felt like a pincushion! And don't even get me started on the costs. I remember the first trimester scan cost me rupees three thousand five hundred.

unnormalised: But Dr. Khan really explained everything to me. She gave me this whole rundown of normal fetal development, and what to expect from weeks 1-40 of gestation. She even patiently answered my questions about the potential complications of the pregnancy, and what to do if the unexpected happens.
normalised: But Doctor Khan really explained everything to me. She gave me this whole rundown of normal fetal development, and what to expect from weeks one to forty of gestation. She even patiently answered my questions about the potential complications of the pregnancy, and what to do if the unexpected happens.

unnormalised: And you know, it's not just about the medical side of things. It's about the emotional support too. Dr. Khan always made time to listen to my worries (and there were plenty!). She even helped me navigate some of the trickier conversations with my in-laws. God bless her! She is a true gem.
normalised: And you know, it's not just about the medical side of things. It's about the emotional support too. Doctor Khan always made time to listen to my worries (and there were plenty!). She even helped me navigate some of the trickier conversations with my in-laws. God bless her! She is a true gem.

unnormalised: So, yeah, pregnancy in India is definitely a unique experience. But with the right doctor, a supportive family (and maybe a good supply of chai), it’s totally manageable. And honestly, it's pretty incredible to think I’m going to have a little one of my own soon! Wish me luck! Scheduled for delivery on 25/12/2024. Wish me luck, guys!
normalised: So, yeah, pregnancy in India is definitely a unique experience. But with the right doctor, a supportive family (and maybe a good supply of chai), it’s totally manageable. And honestly, it's pretty incredible to think I’m going to have a little one of my own soon! Wish me luck! Scheduled for delivery on twenty fifth December two thousand and twenty four. Wish me luck, guys!
